There are Chinese interpreters, which are a little colder than other museums but also very exciting. Telling about the various uses of royal etiquette since ancient times, you can also see the epitome of the westernization of the modern Korean royal family. It will be more sensational to visit several palaces with an understanding of court life. The museum is free to visit and can be rented at the desk if you need a voice guide. The museum is located inside Gyeongboo Palace, close to the exit of the ticket office. There are a large number of exhibits in the museum, detailing the daily life of the past royal nobles. We spent an hour in it, still not enough, and wanted to stay longer.

The National Palace Museum has a large collection of precious cultural relics! The collections are rich and varied, from ancient calligraphy and painting to ceramic jade, which is dizzying. The exhibition is also carefully arranged, so that you can better appreciate and understand the historical and cultural value of these cultural relics. Moreover, the building itself is also very distinctive, full of classical charm. Going to the National Palace Museum to visit is definitely a cultural feast!
The palace is big! Beautiful architecture! Easy to access the palace by subway. Recommended to visit!
If you are interested in Korean history, this is a must-see place to rent a Chinese interpreter.

Connecting the north and south sides of the Han River, the Ruicao District in the south of the Yangtze River and the Longshan District in the north of the Yangtze River are the first double-decker bridges in South Korea and the longest water spray bridge in the Guinness World Records. Caoxi Temple (조계사) is a temple in downtown Seoul. It is the birthplace of the largest Buddhist sect in South Korea, the Caoxi Temple (a sect of Buddhism), and occupies the leading position in Korean Buddhism. Caoxi Temple was founded in 1395, and now you see Caoxi Temple after reconstruction in 1910. The center of the temple is its main building, the temple is dedicated to the Buddha statue of Sakyamuni Buddha, there is a white pine planted next to the temple, the tree age is nearly 500 years, very rare in South Korea. In addition, a seven-story stone tower in the temple is also dedicated to the 1 piece of the true body of the Buddha of Sakyamuni, gifted by Sri Lanka's Damoporo Master in 1913. Every year around May, the Buddha's birthday day Caoxi Temple Association held the lamp conference, also known as the Lotus Lantern Festival, is the largest Buddhist festival in South Korea. Caoxi Temple also runs a "monastery life" project for foreign tourists to experience Buddhist culture.
